TypeLocality: "Mt. Manning Area, Western Australia Goldfields, 29°58'S, 119°32'E".
"Environs de Mahanara, à 75 km environ au sud de Vohémar, sur la côte nord-est de Madagascar" [Maharana River, 78 km S of Iharana [Vohimarina], Antsiranana, Antalaha, Madagascar (MacPhee, 1987)].
Ambohimitombo forest, Madagascar [Ambohimitombo town, 43 km by road SE of Ambositra, 10 km into eastern forest, Fianarantsoa, 20°43S 47°26E (MacPhee, 1987)].
Ankáfana forest, E Betsileo, Madagascar [Ankafina, Fianarantsoa, Fianarantsoa Province, 21°12S 47°12E (see MacPhee, 1987; Carleton and Schmidt, 1990)].
Ambohimitombo forest, Tanala Country, Madagascar [Ambohimitombo town, 43 km by road SE of Ambositra, 10 km into eastern forest, Fianarantsoa, 20°43S 47°26E (MacPhee, 1987)].
"Ankaye et Antsianak" [Ankay, along the Mangoro River, near Lac Alaotra and Antsianaka, region E of Lac Alaotra, Madagascar (Viette, 1991)].
"Du plateau dEmirne" [Imerina, Madagascar (Viette, 1991)].
"Gulf of Guinea Coast, Congo."
Ethiopia (= Abyssinia).
Senegal
"In India orientali;" redefined as Pernambuco, Brazil, by Sanborn (1930).
"Sudamerika;" restricted to Brazil by Mertens (1925) who suggested that the type may have come from Bahia.
Given as "Pontianak" (Kalimantan, Borneo); with little doubt actually collected by Diard at Cochin Chine, Vietnam (C. Smeenk, in litt.).
Dem. Rep. Congo, upper Congo River.
Dem. Rep. Congo, Republic Poste des Ouaddas (junction of Oubangui and Congo Rivers).
Angola (NW, by lower Congo River). See Machado (1969).
Nigeria, Benin City.
India, Nepal Terai.
Gabon, Gabon Estuary, Mpongwe country.
"in India orientali" [Bombay, India]. Based on "Pennant's Bombay squirrel" (Moore and Tate, 1965:43).
Not known; restricted to Assam, India by Bonhote (1901a); further restricted to the Garo Hills of Assam by Moore and Tate (1965).
"Madaum, 25 feet [8 m] altitude, Tagum Municipality, Davao Province, Mindanao Island, Philippines Islands."
"Cochin China near Saigon," [Vietnam].
Senegal (neotype). Origin of original type unknown. "Inconnue."
"Congo". No specific locale given, probably Angola (Hill and Carter, 1941:71).
Guinea coast, no exact locality given. "...dans toutes les forêts de la Guiné..." Given by Ingoldby (1927) as Ghana: "Secondi and Bibiani, Gold Coast."
"from Sierra Madre, near Guadalupe y Calvo, Chihuahua, Mexico (7,000 feet [2134 m] altitude)."
Germany
Sweden
Japan
Panama, City of Panama (restricted by Goldman, 1920).
USA, San Francisco Mountains, New Mexico (fixed to Arizona, Yuma Co., 1 mi [1.6 km] SW Parker by Hoffmeister and Lee, 1967).
Mexico (restricted to Veracruz, near Jalapa, by Merriam, 1895a).

W Kazakhstan, Kirgiz Steppe. The type locality given by Lichtenstein (1828) is in W Kazakhstan, according to Vinogradov (1937), Kuznetsov (1944, 1965), and Ognev (1963b), not E Kazakhstan as reported by Ellerman and Morrison-Scott (1951:529) and Corbet (1978c:154).
Iraq (no other information).

China, N Xinjiang, Altai Gobi, near Schara-sumé (Sharasume), approx. 160km S Russia-Mongolian border. Most authors list the type locality as being in W Mongolia, but it is actually in N Xinjiang, China (G. Shenbrot, pers. comm.).
Afghanistan or S Tibet (Ognev, 1963b; Vinogradov, 1928).
Egypt, in the "mountains separating Egypt from Arabia" (G. M. Allen, 1939:424).
Gambia, Gambia River.
W Serbia and Montenegro, Rijeka Prov., Montenegro, Cetinje.
Croatia, northwestern segment of Dinaric Alps, Velebit Mtns, summit of Mali Rajinac, 1699 m (Brunet-Lecomte and Krytufek, 1993).
Georgia (Gruzinskaya), Caucasus Mtns, Gudaur, S of Krestovyi Pass, 6500 ft (as given by Ognev, 1963b).
Somalia ("Probably from African coast opposite Aden, where it was purchased," G. M. Allen, 1939:315; also see Thomas, 1910c:222).
Argentina, Entre Ríos Prov., about 30°30'S latitude between the Uruguay and Paraná Rivers.

Paraguay, Neembucú Dept., banks of Río Paraguay about 27º S latitude (refined as opposite mouth of Río Bermejo by Hershkovitz, 1962:172, and restricted as vicinity of Ciudad Pilar by Contreras, 1992:2).
Netherlands West Indies, Curaçao, Klein Santa Martha.
Brazil, SE area along the Río Uruguay (as restricted by Hershkovitz, 1966c:120).
Argentina, Santa Cruz Prov., "interior plains of Patagonia" at 50°S latitude, near the Río Santa Cruz (probably near La Argentina as per Hershkovitz, 1962:392).
N Dem. Rep. Congo, Orientale (Haut-Zaïre), right bank Congo River near Kisangani, Masako Forest Reserve, "rainforest of the Tshoporiver," 440 m, 00EE36'N, 25EE13'E (W. Verheyen et al., 2002:147).
N Dem. Rep. Congo, near village of Yaenero on left side of Congo River, 450 m (see W. Verheyen et al., 1996a, for additional information).
Sahelian region of N Mali, 12 km east of Mopti, Emnalhere, right bank of main course of Niger River (14E28'26" N, 04E05'16" W); Granjon et al. (2002a) provided details of trap location and habitat.

Dem. Rep. Congo, Katanga Province, Marungu, Qua Mpala (see Ansell, 1978, and Hill and Carter, 1941, for placement of type locality in S Dem. Rep. Congo; it has also been identified as N Zambia [G. M. Allen, 1939; Bates, 1988]).
South Africa, Ladybrand, E Free State Province, near Lesotho border (see Meester et al., 1986, for details).
Gambia (see Robbins, 1974).
Nigeria, Lake Chad (= Kaddai).
Burkina Faso (Upper Volta), Oudalan Province, near Oursi Pond; 14EE38'N, 00EE26'W (Sicard et al., 1988:188).
Taiwan (M.-j. Yu, 1996).
NW India (Assam), Khasi Hills, Cherrapunji.
Malaysia (Borneo), Sarawak, Sadong.
Malaysia (Borneo), Sabah, Gunung Kinabalu, Bundu Tuhan, 4000 ft (1220 m).
Malaysia (Borneo), Sabah, Gunung Kinabalu, 1000 ft (305 m).
SE Australia (Neuholland); see Mahoney and Richardson (1988:155).
Ghana (= Gold Coast), Dabocrom.
Morocco (= "Barbaria," see discussion in Carleton and Van der Straeten, 1997).
Senegal (= French Gambia), Gamon.

Papua New Guinea (= "British New Guinea"), Central Province, Astrolabe Range behind Port Moresby. The specimen was collected by Dr. Lamberto Loria between 1890 and 1893 and Tate (1951:223) claimed that "Loria collected in the Astrolabe Range behind Port Moresby," but Laurie and Hill, 1954:132 noted that no exact locality was published. Thomas (1897a:4), however wrote that Lorias localities "are mostly between the Owen Stanley Range and the sea, in or near the watershed of the Kemp Welch river," an area that would include the Astrolabe Range and adjacent Sogeri Plateau.
Liberia Mellacoree River (= Melikhoure River, Guinea according to Rautenbach and Schlitter, 1978:410).
Somalia (British Somaliland), Upper Sheikh.
India (uncertain).
Malaysia (Malay Peninsula), S Perak, Sungkei.
Indonesia, Nusa Tenggara, Palau Flores, Manggarai Province, Liang Toge, a cave near Warukia, 1 km S Lepa.
Kenya (Kenya Colony), Machakos.
Cameroon, Cameroon Mountains, 7000 ft.
Cameroon, "Efulen, Cameroon district, West Africa".
Kenya, Naivasha Prov., Mordat, mile 365 of Uganda Railway.
Senegal, upper Senegal River, Medina District, Felou.
Somalia (between Goree Bunder and Nogal, ca. 09°N, 47° E).
"Asia", restricted to near Rome, Italy by Thomas (1911a:141).
E Canada (= Quebec Prov.).
Peru Puno Dept., Pisacoma.
Brazil, Pará. Original designation of Guyana was probably an error (Cabrera, 1961:588).

Argentina, Central Pampas, 780 km SW Buenos Aires (37<sup>o</sup>45S, 65<sup>o</sup>W). Type location originally given as Sapucay, Paraguay (Thomas, 1903) but corrected to 780 km SW Buenos Aires by Thomas (1903). The type locality corresponds approximately to General Acha, La Pampa Province (Tate, 1935).
Chile, Prov. General Carrera, about 2 km S Chile Chico and 1 km W Chile Chico aerodromo (46<sup>o</sup>33S, 71<sup>o</sup>46W).
Brazil, S provinces, and banks of Uruguay River. See Moojen (1952:188).
"...in mountains near Vernyi[Alma-ata]...7000-8000 ft." [2134-2438 m]. Restricted by Shnitnikov (1936) to valley of Maly Alma-atinsk River, Zailisk Alatau Mtns, Kazakhstan (43E05'N, 77E10'E).
"Valley of Alyk-nor." Restricted by Formosov (in A. T. Smith et al., 1990) to Alang-nor Lake, NE Qinghai, China (35E35'N, 97E25'E); see also Corbet (1978c).
Not stated; restricted by Trouessart (1910), to Poland (see discussion in Ognev, 1940:140, who further restricted it to SW Poland).
Probably Senegal or Gambia; see Allen (1939:20).
Nigeria, "Asaba, 150 mi. [241 km] up the Niger River".
"Nguruman"; northwest of Lake Natron, close to Mt. Sambo, Kenya (near border to Tanzania); see discussion by Moreau et al. (1946) and Aggundey and Schlitter (1986).
"Chaya, near Ruchuru, Congo Belge."
Morocco, between Morocco City and Mogador, Sierzet.
Cameroon Mountains.
USA, Texas, El Paso Co., 2 mi. (3.2 km) above El Paso, "near Fort Bliss, New Mexico (Practically El Paso Texas)." (Merriam, 1895b:32).
"in Europe cryptis"; restricted to Uppsala, Sweden by Thomas (1911a:143).
"Tokiwa Mura (Maneki, about 900 m altitude, foot of Mt. Gaki, Japan Alps), Kita-Azumi Gun, Nagano Pref., Central Honsyû [= Honshu], Japan".
"Orizaba, Veracruz, Mexico (altitude 4,200 feet [1280 m])."
"Sierra de Colima, Jalisco, Mexico (altitude 10,000 feet) [= 3,048 m]".
"Tumbala, Chiapas, Mexico (alt. 5000 ft. [1524 m])"
"Cerro San Felipe, Oaxaca, Mexico (altitude 1000 feet [305 m])."
Serbia and Montenegro, Pelister Mtns, "Magarevo Mts., Perister, S. Serbia (Macedonia). Alt. 1000 m."
Malaysia (N Borneo), Sabah, Mt. Kinabalu, 5,500 ft. (1,833 m).
Malaysia (N Borneo), Sarawak.
Senegal (restricted by K. Andersen, 1907).
Fiji Isls, Viti Levu.
Fiji Isls, Taveuni Isl, Des Voeux Peak, ca. 3,840 ft. (1,170 m).
Solomon Isls, New Georgia Isl, Marovo Lagoon, 5 km N of Patutiva Village, Mt Javi, 8°31'S, 157°52'E, 50 m.
Micronesia, Caroline Isls, Palau Isl (= Pelew Isls).
Micronesia, Caroline Isls, Palau Isls (= Pelew Isls).
Tonga Isls, Tongatapu Isl.
SE Europe; restricted to Italy by Ellerman et al. (1953:59).
Solomon Isls, New Georgia Group, Rubiana Isl.
Barbados (Lesser Antilles), St. Michael Parish.
Dominica (Lesser Antilles).
Honduras (= Río Segovia) (McCarthy et al., 1993).
Mozambique, Mozambique Isl (15°S, 40°42'E).
Nigeria, Mid-Western Region, Benin City.
Mozambique, Mozambique Isl, 15°S.
Restricted by Kock (1969a) to the Nile Valley between north of Aswan, Egypt and Chondek, Sudan.
Nigeria, Abo (lower Niger River).
Dominica (Lesser Antilles).
Hungary (Pliocene). See discussion in Horácek et al. (2000).

"Nous ne savons pas au juste dans quelle partie du globe a été trouvé"; fixed by Van Mensch and Van Bree (1969) to "probably the coastal region of Lower Guinea (Between Cross River and River Congo. . .)".

Not given. Fixed by Temminck (1841) as "Nepal". Gray (1864) discounted this because he knew of no specimens from Nepal, and reassigned the name to two specimens from Canton, China collected by J. R. Reeve (Pocock, 1934b).
"Hinterlang von Togo von 9° n. Br. ab.", restricted to "Borogu = Borgou, (10.78 N., 0.65 E)" by Schlawe (1981:159).

"Entebbe, Uganda". Subsequently restricted by Moreau et al. (1946:410) to "Near Lupanzula's, ten miles [16 km] west of Beni, Ituri Forest, Congo Belge [Dem. Rep. Congo]". See Allen (1924) for discussion.

"fifteen to twenty miles [24 to 32 km] west of the Putu Mountains, which lie west of the Duobe and Cavally Rivers. The Cavally River is the eastern boundary line between Liberia and the Côte dIvoire, and the Duobe is one of its tributaries joining the Cavally about seventy miles [113 km], as the crow flies, from its mouth, after running for over one hundred miles [161 km] nearly parallel to the main stream" [Liberia].
"Ubangi, Congo Belge", restricted by Moreau et al. (1945:410) to "on the Upper Kemo, a tributary to the north of the Ubangui, about 6°17'N, 19°12'E" [Central African Republic].

"Gabridehari, 60 mi [96 km] West of Gerlogobi", restricted by Moreau et al. (1946:410) to "south-east Ethiopia (Ogaden) at about 7°0'N, 45°20'E". Further restricted by Yalden et al. (1980) to "Gabridehari (= Gabredarre, Kebridar) 6°45'N, 44°17'E".
"in Ægypto ad ripas Nili, ...in India primario; mansuescit", restricted by Thomas (1911a) to "Egypt".
"Rio das Velhas's Floddal" Lagoa Santa, Minas Gerais, Brazil (Zunino et al., 1995).
"Man findet das Vison in Canada un Pensilvanien". Larivière (1999c) listed type locality as "Eastern Canada".
"Gebirgs-Gegenden nordwestlich von der Stadt Mexico." [Mexico, mountains NW of Mexico City].

"Er ist, der Sage nach, auf den Gebirgen in Jamaica einheimisch"; restricted by Thomas (1902b) to "Surinam". Ford and Hoffmann (1988) and Husson (1978) discussed the confusion over the name and type locality.
"Habitat in Africa" (West Africa); based on animals exported to Brazil (Simoons, 1953).

"Habitat in Mexici, Panamae, Brasiliae montibus, sylvis". Mexico selected by Thomas (1911a:140); however, Linnaeus's name Sus tajacu is based on the tajacu of Marcgraf, from Brazil, Pernambuco (Cabrera, 1961:319; Hershkovitz, 1963, 1987b) and this restriction of the type locality is adopted here.
"Habitat in Nilo & Bambolo Africae et ad ostia fluviorum Asiae"; restricted to River Nile (Thomas, 1911a:155) in Egypt (G. M. Allen, 1939:457).
"Habitat in Africae desertis arenosis siticulosis", identified as "deserts of Libya and Arabia" by Thomas (1911a:150); based on domesticated stock.
India or Pakistan, "Kashmir (no precise locality)".
"Habitat in boroealibus Europae, Asiaeque Populetis"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).
"Habitat in Europa, Asia"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).
"Bewohnt in grossen Heerden Carolina v), Virginien, Louisiana w), und geht vielleicht bis Panama x) hinunter"; restricted by Hershkovitz (1948c:43) to USA, Virginia.
"Habitat in Europa, Asia"; identified as S Sweden by Thomas (1911a:151).
"Habitat in Europa"; identified as "Habitat in vivariis Regis & Magnatum" by Thomas (1911a:151), in Sweden to which it had been introduced.

Vietnam, "in the west of Quang Nam province"; "collected from four houses in three locations in Hien District, West Quang Nam Province, Vietnam  The three locations are: Hien, the District capital, A Tin village, and A Plo village (15°56'59''N, 107°34'18''E)" (Giao et al., 1998). The type locality is one of these three places.
"probably inhabiting Siam [Thailand]"; occurrence in central plains of Thailand since confirmed.
"transmitted  from Singapore  Hab. Malayan peninsula, or adjoining islands (?)"; "Philippines, the type specimen having been received from Manila" (Lydekker, 1915:63).

No locality cited but the name is based on "Le bubale" of Buffon, "en Barbarie & dans toutes les parties septentrionales de l'Afrique", and on other sources. Restricted to Barbary by designation of the "Vache de Barbarie" of Perrault as the lectotype (Ruxton and Schwarz, 1929:575). Further restricted to Morocco (Lydekker, 1914a:5).
"Muku Muku Flats, Luapala Province, north east Zambia 12°21'S; 30°00'E".
"the range of country from Kilimanjaro to Baringo and at various heights above 6000' [1829 m]"; restricted to "Kilimanjaro district" (Lydekker, 1914b:84) in Kenya (G. M. Allen, 1939:526).
"Habitat in Africa"; restricted to Lower Egypt by Blaine (1913:292), west of the Nile River (Osborn and Helmy, 1980:508).
"Vu Quang Nature Reserve, Vietnam 105°25'E by 18°15'N".
"Habitat in montosis"; identified as Sweden (Thomas, 1911a:152), based on domesticated stock.

Egypt, "de la Haute-Égypte  ou de Nubie"; Nubia (Lydekker, 1913:153; G. M. Allen, 1939:549) or Upper Egypt (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott, 1951:407), which are virtually synonymous; here restricted to Sudan, Northern Prov., Nubian Desert, east of Nile River.
"the central region, equidistant from the snows on one hand, and the plains of India on the other;  between the Sutlege, west, and the Teesta, east,  in Nepal proper" (Nepal, Himalayas).
"Habitat in siccis apricis calidis"; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:153); domesticated stock.
"Africa occidentalis (Gabun)" (Gabon, Gabon River).
None given, listed as Pacific Ocean, off the coast of Chile by Gray (1850:112).
Pacific Ocean, "entre la Nouvelle-Hollande et le cap Horn [= between Australia and Cape Horn]...par 49 [S] de latitude".
"an der östlichen Küste von Südamerika; wir karpunirten ihn in der Gegend des Rio de la Plata." (= South Atlantic Ocean near Rio de la Plata, off coast of Argentina and Uruguay).
